summary.p: This book, titled vyākaraṇasya sūtrāṇi in Sanskrit and The Rules of Grammar in English, is a copy of Vopadeva's Mugdhabodha grammar from the 13th century, with a facing English translation. Of the text, Hartmut Scharfe writes, Vopadeva's most striking innovation is his algebraic terminology that goes far beyond that of Pāṇini and Devanandin; even the sound table has been altered to fit the peculiar design of the grammar. The author's originality, in the long run, was detrimental to his success: literary commentaries written with references to Panini's grammar and the grammatical classics themselves were closed books to the students of the Mugdhabodha (1977, 189).

The Mugdhabodha is normally comprised of 1184 sūtras. The last sūtra, bahulaṃ brahmaṇi, is here numbered 1177. This is also where the translation stops. A double line is drawn below it, and the following lines — numbered 1178-1183 — do not appear in any edition of the text. Some can be found in the Kāśikāvṛtti, while one of them is quoted in the Śabdakalpadruma, under the definition of sāmīpyaṃ: vaḥ kasāmīpyasādṛśya sākalyānukramardhiṣu | iti mugdhabodhavyākaraṇam (1877, 5421).

The text is followed by an index (which, notably, indexes lines 1178-1183), a section on Examples to the Rules: Orthography, Formation and Declension of Nouns, and Formation and Conjugation of Verbs. Finally, there are some additional declension tables. A leaf at the end contains some notes on astrology and a table of the Persian alphabet.
There is a note pasted to the inside back cover, addressed to John Bentley. This book may have belonged to him, or it may even have been his work.
